chapter.title: Using Disnix as a remote package deployer
chapter.para: As described in the previous chapters, Disnix's primary purpose is deploying systems that can be decomposed into services to networks of machines. However, a service deployment process is basically a superset of an "ordinary" package deployment process. This chapter describes how we can do remote package deployment by instructing Disnix to only use a relevant subset of features.

section.title: Specifying packages as services
section.para: In Nixpkgs, it is a common habit to write each package specification as a function in which the parameters denote intra-dependencies. In we have shown that Disnix services follow the same convention and extend this approach with nested functions in which the inner function takes inter-dependencies into account.

section.title: Composing packages locally
section.para: Package and service expressions are functions that do not specify the versions or variants of the dependencies that should be used. To allow services to be deployed, we must compose them by providing the desired versions or variants of the dependencies as function parameters.
As shown in we have to compose a Disnix service twice -- first its intra-dependencies in a composition expression and later its inter-dependencies in the services model.

example.title: Composing packages locally

section.para: composes the Midnight Commander package by providing its intra-dependencies as function parameters. The third attribute (mc) invokes a function named: callPackage {} that imports the previous package expression and automatically provides the parameters having the same names as the function parameters. The callPackage { } function first consults the self attribute set (that composes some of Midnight Commander's dependencies as well, such as gpm and pkgconfig) and then any package from the Nixpkgs repository.

section.title: Writing a packages model
section.para: Disnix provides first-class support to deploy packages to machines remotely. A packages model can be used to specify for each target machine in the network, which packages it should deploy as part of a Nix profile:

example.title: A packages model

section.para: The shows an example packages model that distributes GPM and Midnight Command to machine test1 and pkgconfig to test2. Disnix will automatically instruct Nix to compile it for the corresponding system architecture of the target machine.

section.title: Deploying a packages model
section.para: We can write an infrastructure model with target machines to remotely deploy packcages:

example.title: A basic infrastructure model for package deployment

section.para: describes two machines that have hostname test1 and test2. Furthermore, machine test2 has a specific system architecture: x86_64-darwin that corresponds to a 64-bit Intel-based Mac OS X.

With the following command-line instruction the packages in the packages model can be deployed to the target machines defined in the infrastructure model:
$ disnix-env -i infrastructure.nix -P packages.nix
The above command will build the packages from source code, distribute the packages and their dependencies to the target machines and switch the current symlink generations of the Nix profiles.

Alternatively, packages can also be built on the target machines through Disnix instead of the coordinator machine:
$ disnix-env --build-on-targets -i infrastructure.nix -P packages.nix

It is also possible to combine a packages model with the traditional three Disnix input models:
$ disnix-env -s services.nix -i infrastructure.nix -d distribution.nix -P packages.nix
When combining a packages model with the traditional three Disnix models, it is possible to deploy additional supplemental packages in conjunction with the services that Disnix deploys.

section.title: Writing a minimal services model for deploying packages
section.para: In addition to a packages model that specifies which packages to install on each target machine in the network, it is also possible to expose services in the services model as "ordinary" packages by annotating them with a type that refers to package. This could be useful to slowly migrate a deployment process that is package-based to a service-based deployment process.
Services that are exposed as packages can also have inter-dependencies on services allowing you to deploy a client that automatically connects to a backend service.

section.title: Deploying packages
section.para: By providing an infrastructure model and distribution model, we can use Disnix to deploy services exposed as packages to remote machines.

example.title: A basic distribution model for package deployment

section.para: In , we distribute package gpm to machine test1, pkgconfig to machine test2 and mc to both machines.

When running the following command-line instruction:
$ disnix-env -s services.nix -i infrastructure.nix -d distribution.nix
Disnix executes all activities to get the packages in the distribution model deployed to the machines, such as building them from source code (including its dependencies), and distributing their dependency closures to the target machines. Because machine test2 may have a different system architecture as the coordinator machine, Disnix can use Nix's delegation mechanism to forward a build to a machine that is capable of doing it.

Alternatively, packages can also be built on the target machines through Disnix:
$ disnix-env --build-on-targets -s services.nix -i infrastructure.nix -d distribution.nix

After the deployment above command-line instructions have succeeded, we should be able to start the Midnight Commander on any of the target machines, by running:
$ mc

section.title: Configuring the remote machine's search paths
section.para:
To allow users on the remote machines to conveniently access their packages, we must add Disnix' Nix profile to the PATH of a user on the remote machines:
$ export PATH=/nix/var/nix/profiles/disnix/default/bin:$PATH

When using NixOS, this variable can be extended by adding the following line to /etc/nixos/configuration.nix:
environment.variables.PATH = [ "/nix/var/nix/profiles/disnix/default/bin" ];

section.title: Deploying any package as a service from the Nixpkgs repository
section.para: Besides exposing custom packages as a service, it is also possible to use Disnix to remotely deploy any package in the Nixpkgs repository as a service, but doing so is a bit tricky. The main challenge lies in the fact that the Nix packages set is a nested set of attributes, whereas Disnix expects services to be addressed in one attribute set only.

section.title: Multi-user package management
section.para:
Besides supporting single user installations, Nix also supports multi-user installations in which every user has its own private Nix profile with its own set of packages. With Disnix we can also manage multiple profiles. For example, by adding the --profile parameter, we can deploy another Nix profile that, for example, contains a set of packages for the user: sander:
$ disnix-env -s services.nix -i infrastructure.nix -d distribution.nix --profile sander
The user: sander can access its own set of packages by setting the PATH environment variable to:
$ export PATH=/nix/var/nix/profiles/disnix/sander:$PATH
